H0.text: Rolling one ball toward another and seeing what happens when they collide is an investigation that might be used to demonstrate potential energy.

H1.text: Placing a glass of water in the freezer and observing how long it takes to freeze is an investigation that might be used to demonstrate potential energy.

H2.text: Compressing a spring by different amounts and seeing how far it can launch a ball into the air is an investigation that might be used to demonstrate potential energy.

H3.text: Rolling a ball from the top of an inclined plane and determining the amount of time it takes to reach the bottom is an investigation that might be used to demonstrate potential energy.

A4.text: When an object returns to its original shape, the stored elastic energy is converted into kinetic energy and sound energy.

A5.text: The elastic potential energy stored in a compressed spring can be calculated using the formula U = ½k(Δx)².

A6.text: Gravitational potential energy increases when two objects are brought further apart and is converted to kinetic energy as they are allowed to fall towards each other.

A7.text: Gravitational potential energy being the minimum (quasi-static) work that needs to be done against gravitational force in this procedure
